abstracts.cdata!:
Overall the outcome of the project is
            rated satisfactory: the project resulted in a stronger and
            modernized technical training structure. Project
            sustainability is likely. Both World Bank and Borrower
            performances are rated satisfactory. Best practice in
            identifying needed reforms in technical training programs
            was reflected in using panels of experts at national and
            state levels, including curricula specialists,
            representatives of the productive sectors, and education
            specialists. Expanding the scope of activities for the
            technical education school (CONALEP) transformed the
            institution from a strictly pre-work technical training
            agency to a comprehensive system offering pre- and
            on-the-job training, technical assistance, and quality and
            productivity enhancement to industry, and represents a good
            model. An important lesson was learned from the lack of
            success of regional maintenance centers and the better
            results achieved by assigning building and equipment
            maintenance responsibilities to each training center,
            allowing them to use private contractors to maintain major
            equipment. A more conclusive analysis of costs in relation
            to outcomes would have provided a firmer basis to guide
            resource allocation among programs and fine-tuned training
            activities. The flexible staffing policies adopted by
            CONALEP was a key factor in modernizing the institution and
            provided an important lesson about the central role played
            by personnel policies during institutional change.
